title: Why did Germany make so many types of tanks during World War 2 instead of just focusing on one design like the US and Soviet Union for maximum output efficiency? - Quora
tags: Military History and Wars of Germany

response.answer_text: A very good question. Germany had supply shortages long before the war. They knew that the combined allied production could outproduce that. The Germans did have a few main battle tanks such as the Sturmgeschutz variants and the panzer iii and iv. Also the tiger tanks and it’s variants and also the panther tanks (panzer v) The Germans opted for reliability rather then quantity. Their formations were also not tank heavy. The Germans were reluctant into engaging into tank on tank warfare. This can be seen in Rommel’s tactics in North Africa, where he would bait British tanks into kill zones where anti tank guns and infantry would wait for them. The Germans knew that tank on tank warfare was bad. The constant need to replace tanks would drain resources they could have used elsewhere. The large number of tanks would either make good target practice for enemy aircraft and it would consume too much fuel. The focus on reliability has more tactical value. German attack formations would not be with tanks first, as it is motorized divisions and infantry who would need to start a fire fight and only then for the tanks to engage an enemy and support infantry on infantry. The Germans adopted this tactic earlier in the war. The allies only learned this much later that combined arms warfare is good. As for the variations, the Germans had to keep producing better tanks, as the allies were now producing better anti tank guns, which could be easily moved around (towed) and set up faster. The Germans had to opt for thicker front armor and more sloped designs. The later model tanks were also designed to travel faster then earlier models. When you think of tank destroyer tanks, do not look at games and movies. These tanks were mainly used to ambush enemy tank formations by destroying the first tank in the column and then the last tank. This would create confusion and the German tank crews would have time to eliminate as many tanks as possible. The tank formations were also very versatile, with only one tiger with a number of other tanks, as they were not such a common sight on the battlefield as believed. The Germans had to build tanks to suite their current needs. If they did not build better tanks, they would lose more tanks. If they built more tanks, they would lose resources. Each tank also had a specific purpose and in their tanker training it was sufficiently outlined how tank formations battle orders go. They would have to use these powerful tanks to their advantage as not many would come around. Staying with one design too long makes it obsolete. Making many cheaper ones, drops their resource supplies. There wasn’t much oil, nor exotic metals for proper Luftwaffe support.

Well the question is wrong The germans did use many types of tanks (as seen below) and self propelled guns, but so did the US and USSR (more seen below). This is because they had to build an entire armoured force during the war-so using existing chassis and updating them was all they could do, as well as using everything else they took.
